summary: This document is email correspondence between legal teams (defense and prosecution) regarding jury selection for an upcoming trial. They discuss exchanging lists of proposed juror strikes and coordinating a joint submission to the court, categorizing jurors as joint keeps, joint strikes, government-only strikes, and defense-only strikes.

persons.name: Menninger
persons.context: Appears to be a government attorney (likely Assistant United States Attorney) corresponding with the defense team about coordinating juror strike lists and preparing a joint submission to the court.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney corresponding with the prosecution team about the process for exchanging juror strike lists and preparing the joint court submission.

persons.name: Ann Lundberg
persons.context: Appears to be a paralegal or legal staff member for the defense team, involved in compiling the list of proposed juror strikes and discussing file format issues.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney communicating with the prosecution about the timing for exchanging juror strike lists and coordinating the joint submission.

Both appear to be defense attorneys working together on the case, coordinating with the prosecution team.

events.title: Juror Strike List Exchange
events.description: Legal teams exchange their lists of proposed juror strikes by noon to compile data for the joint court submission.

keyFacts: The document reveals coordination between prosecution and defense teams on jury selection for an upcoming trial, indicating active pretrial proceedings in late 2021.
Three specific jurors (numbers 127, 151, and 458) are mentioned where the defense withdrew objections and agreed they should proceed to voir dire.
The legal teams are preparing a joint submission to the court categorizing jurors into four groups: joint keeps, joint strikes, government-only strikes, and defense-only strikes.
The correspondence shows procedural collaboration between adversarial parties on logistical matters like file formats (Excel vs. PDF) and timing of document exchanges.
